claim: Library of Alexandria would need less shelf space than Library of Congress.

supporting.text: The Library of Alexandria, estimated to have held around 400,000 scrolls, is significantly smaller than the Library of Congress, which holds over 170 million items.

attacks.text: The Library of Alexandria, estimated to have held around 400,000 scrolls, is significantly smaller than the Library of Congress, which holds over 170 million items.
Scrolls in the Library of Alexandria were often long and required more physical space per unit of content compared to modern books or digital media in the Library of Congress.
The Library of Congress includes many small or compact items (e.g., pamphlets, microfilms, digital files) that occupy less space than scrolls, making direct volume comparisons misleading.
The Library of Alexandria's collection was concentrated in a single location, whereas the Library of Congress is distributed across multiple buildings, complicating shelf-space comparisons.
Even if distributed, the Library of Congress's total shelf space across all facilities still vastly exceeds the estimated space needed for the Library of Alexandria's scrolls.

supporting.text: Modern printed books and digital media in the Library of Congress require more physical and digital storage space compared to the compact scrolls used in the Library of Alexandria.

attacks.text: Modern printed books and digital media in the Library of Congress require more physical and digital storage space compared to the compact scrolls used in the Library of Alexandria.
The Library of Alexandria contained a vast number of scrolls, potentially rivaling or exceeding the volume of modern printed books when accounting for storage inefficiencies.
Scrolls were often stored in tightly packed cylindrical cases, optimizing space more efficiently than modern bookshelves.
Digital media in the Library of Congress requires negligible physical space compared to scrolls or printed books, contradicting the claim about digital storage.
Digital storage still requires significant infrastructure (servers, cooling, backups), which may not be as space-efficient as scroll storage in practice.

supporting.text: The Library of Congress includes diverse formats such as maps, recordings, and photographs, which occupy more space than the primarily text-based scrolls of the Library of Alexandria.

attacks.text: The Library of Congress includes diverse formats such as maps, recordings, and photographs, which occupy more space than the primarily text-based scrolls of the Library of Alexandria.
The Library of Alexandria also housed non-textual items like maps, artworks, and scientific instruments, which could have occupied significant space.
Historical records suggest the non-textual items in the Library of Alexandria were a small fraction compared to its vast collection of scrolls, limiting their impact on total shelf space.
Modern digital storage in the Library of Congress reduces physical space needs, making direct comparison with ancient scroll storage misleading.
Digital storage is a recent addition; the Library of Congress's physical collections (books, maps, etc.) still vastly exceed the space efficiency of scrolls.

supporting.text: The Library of Congress serves as a comprehensive repository for U.S. copyright deposits, necessitating vast storage, while the Library of Alexandria focused on a curated collection of ancient knowledge.

attacks.text: The Library of Congress serves as a comprehensive repository for U.S. copyright deposits, necessitating vast storage, while the Library of Alexandria focused on a curated collection of ancient knowledge.
The Library of Alexandria's collection was vast and included works from many cultures, potentially rivaling the Library of Congress in size despite its curated nature.

Ancient texts were often written on scrolls or codices, which took up more physical space per unit of information compared to modern books, potentially increasing the Library of Alexandria's shelf space needs.
The Library of Congress includes digital and non-print materials, which require minimal physical space compared to the entirely physical collection of the Library of Alexandria.
The Library of Alexandria's collection was repeatedly damaged or destroyed over time, making it difficult to accurately assess its original size and storage needs.

supporting.text: The physical dimensions of modern books are larger than ancient scrolls, meaning the same amount of content would occupy more shelf space in the Library of Congress.

attacks.text: The physical dimensions of modern books are larger than ancient scrolls, meaning the same amount of content would occupy more shelf space in the Library of Congress.
Modern books can store significantly more content per volume than ancient scrolls, reducing the total number of physical items needed for the same amount of information.
Ancient scrolls were often written on both sides (opisthographs), effectively doubling their content capacity compared to modern books, which are typically printed on one side per page.
The Library of Congress includes digital and non-book materials (e.g., maps, recordings), which require specialized storage solutions not directly comparable to scroll-based libraries.
Ancient scrolls were stored in compact cylindrical cases, allowing for efficient stacking and space utilization compared to modern shelving systems for books.

supporting.text: The Library of Congress maintains extensive archival and preservation facilities for fragile materials, further increasing its spatial requirements compared to the simpler storage methods of the Library of Alexandria.

attacks.text: The Library of Congress maintains extensive archival and preservation facilities for fragile materials, further increasing its spatial requirements compared to the simpler storage methods of the Library of Alexandria.
The Library of Alexandria also stored fragile materials, such as papyrus scrolls, which required climate-controlled environments to prevent decay, similar to modern preservation needs.
Modern archival techniques are far more space-efficient than ancient methods, as digitization and compact storage solutions reduce the physical footprint required for preservation.
The sheer volume of materials in the Library of Congress, including millions of books, recordings, and digital media, vastly exceeds the estimated holdings of the Library of Alexandria.
The Library of Alexandria's collection was vast for its time, and if scaled to modern information density, its physical storage needs might rival contemporary libraries.
